history.content:
1. If you have units that are taken during high school whether at community college, regular college, or AP credit units all of them could be omitted from the 130 unit cap. That is, you can ask them to deduct high school credits from your total. As long as you stay under 130 units, you can request an extra semester until you hit 130.

2. Only take classes needed for your degree. Audit any unneeded units so you stay under the 130 unit cap.

2. Only take classes needed for your degree. Audit any unneeded units so you stay under the 130 unit cap.

2. Only take classes needed for your degree. Audit any unneeded units so you stay under the 130 unit cap.

children.subject: I strongly suggest talking to an advisor about this

Can someone clarify the study abroad rules? If I am double-majoring, and take 8 semesters at Berkeley and one semester studying abroad, do I get one extra semester at Berkeley, even if I'm well over the unit cap? That would mean I have 9 semesters at Berkeley and 10 semesters in total. (by semester I mean academic year semester, not summers)

history.content: I spoke with L&S advising a while ago and they essentially told me that students can't keep taking classes after 8 semesters (unless that have a really low number of units, and I have a lot) and they're basically forced to graduate on time. Though, they also said that if I'm double majoring I would be allowed one extra fall semester, as well as the option to enroll in more classes during the summer session after that fall (skipping spring completely). Can someone verify if this is true? I am planning to double major but I don't think I would be able to fit everything in to even that number of semesters, and I would probably need one more. I have already spent every summer so far taking summer classes. I also heard that studying abroad doesn't count toward your max semesters, and if this is true then would it be wiser for me to do it during the academic year or the summer?
history.subject: L&S Rules for graduating late
